sender.senderstreetaddress: Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corp. Bldg 419, One Health Plaza

reaction.primarysourcereaction: Previous neutropenia while on generic clozapine / neutrophil count as 1.40 x 10^9/L

summary.narrativeincludeclinical:
Case number PHHY2012AU084792 is an initial PMS report received from a physician on 27 Sep 2012 with follow-up report received from pharmacist on 29 Oct 2012 with follow up report received from pharmacist on 07 Nov 2012 with follow-up report received from pharmacist on 23 Jan 2013: This report refers to a 32-year-old male patient (CPN No.JG15294). The patient's current condition included the patient had not been swallowing tablets, patient secretly hiding medication for approximate a week. Concomitant medication includes vitamin D/calcium at a dose of one dosage form (12.5mcg/600mg) oral once a day since Nov 2011 as vitamin D supplementation for osteoporosis protection. The patient received Clozaril (clozapine) tablet orally for the treatment of schizophrenia from 11 Jan 2005 at a dose of 400mg. Treatment with Clozaril was discontinued in Jan 2006. The patient also received Clozapine (manufacturer unknown) generic tablet orally at an unspecified indication and dose from 2006 (unspecified date and month). During the time of clozapine generic the patient experienced amber and red range blood result (neutropenia) and the patient had glandular fever at the time of the red result in 2007. On 23 Feb 2007, patient had neutrophil count as 1.40 x 10^9/L. On 11 Oct 2012, patient recommenced Clozaril with 200 mg. Patient had been palming doses for approximately 5 to10 days therefore not had doses since then. When questioned /challenged by staff about something, the patient apparently took 2 x 100mg tablets he had stashed in the evening time on 27 Oct 2012. On 28 Oct 2012, patient took 200 mg dose. On 28 Oct 2012 the patient's pulse rate was approximately 140 beats per minute (bpm) at 3.00pm and blood pressure was (136/88). Pulse rate was 108 bpm and blood pressure was 143/86 at 8.00pm. On 29 Oct 2012 the patient received Clozaril at dose of 200mg. Treatment with Clozaril was temporarily interrupted. On 29 Oct 2012 (previously reported as 28 Oct 2012), the patient developed sinus tachycardia (heart rate: 140 bpm) and sedation. On 30 Oct 2012 the dose of Clozaril was reiterated to 200 mg dose. Pharmacist reported that patient was ok. Reporter stated that the patient had not been swallowing tablets since he recommenced therefore he would be recommenced again on 30 Oct 2012. On 30 Oct 2012 the patient's clozapine/norclozapine levels were 107/83 microgram/L (ref range: 350-600 microgram/L). On an unknown date the patient suffered from fainting, dizziness. The patient experienced sedation all day. At the time of reporting treatment with Clozaril was ongoing and for Clozapine was discontinued on unknown date. The seriousness criterion of the events glandular fever and neutrophil count as 1.40 x 10^9/L was reported as hospitalized, for the events sinus tachycardia and sedation was reported as non-seriousness and for other events was not reported. The outcome of the event tachycardia and sedation was reported as complete recovered on 30 Oct 2012 (previously reported as 29 Oct 2012) and for other events was not reported. Causality of the events tachycardia and sedation was reported suspected with Clozaril and for other events was not reported.
Follow-up report received from pharmacist via CPMS (Clozaril Patient Monitoring Services) on 29 Oct 2012: Updated reporter's information, laboratory data, suspect drug information and event verbatim (neutropenia). Added events (sinus tachycardia and sedation).
Follow-up report received from pharmacist on 07 Nov 2012: The patient's lab data of (28 Oct 2012 and 30 Oct 2012) and (clozapine/norclozapine level and blood pressure), suspect drug indication, dosage regimens and action taken, concomitant medication, stop date, outcome and causality of the events (sinus tachycardia and sedation), new events (clozapine/norclozapine levels were 107/83 microgram/L, fainting, dizziness and blood pressure was 143/86) updated.
Follow-up report received from pharmacist on 23 Jan 2013: Medical history (secretly hiding medication), concomitant drug information (dose), suspect drug information (titrated dose), event onset dates and event end date (sinus tachycardia and sedation) were added.
summary.sendercomment: MR for Clozaril/clozapine: Based on Review of available reported data does not allow for a proper causality assessment. Reported event infectious mononucleosis is unassessable
